trial_identification.studytitle: Vitamin C levels in hospitalised patients
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Vitamin C levels in hospitalised patients

interventions.interventions: To determine Vitamin C levels in patients admitted under General Medicine. Blood sample will be collected once at admission for determination of Vitamin C levels.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Prevalence of Vitamin C deficiency in general medical hospitalised patients. Vitamin C levels will be determined in blood samples taken at the time of hospital admission.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life as determined by EQ5D (European Quality of Life) questionnaire
association with cognitive decline assessed by Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE).
Length of hospital stay will be recorded from hospital admission database.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At the time of hospital discharge.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: association with the Nutrition status assessed by Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST).

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: All patients admitted under General Medicine

trial_design.statisticalmethods: Basic descriptive statistics will be used to describe patients' characteristics and sk test will be utilized to test normality of variables. The continuous variables will be expressed as mean (SD) or median (Inter quartile range) and categorical variables as n (%) and student t test or Mann Whitney U test will be used to analyze continuous variables and categorical variables will be assessed using chi2 or Fisher's exact test where appropriate. Regression models will be used to test association of Vitamin C deficiency with cognitive status with adjustment for any confounding variables.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: It is well known that severe Vitamin C deficiency can lead to gum disease, bleeding and poor wound healing but the effect of mild to moderately low levels in hospitalised patients is less known. This research endeavours to review the effect of Vitamin C deficiency in the unwell person and how it affects recovery. The aims of the present study is to examine Vitamin C levels in hospitalised patients and determine possible correlation with cognition, severity of illness and clinical course in hospital. This study will involve addition of Vitamin C levels in blood samples after informed consent from the patients, admitted in General Medicine Department of Flinders Medical Centre. The nutrition status of the participants will be determined using Malnutirition Universal Screening Tool (MUST) and quality of life will be assessed using European Quality of life Questionnaire (EQ5D). The patients will be followed onto the discharge for development of complications during hospital stay and hospital lenght of stay will be recorded.
